plugins.name: JSON Frame Mapper
plugins.description: # JSON Frame Mapper: Figma Plugin## Main use caseYou have a number of items with data in a collection as a single source of truth.You also have a Figma design which you would like to use as a template.You would like to create as many items as you have in your collection, with the data from each item using your Figma design as a template.Wouldn't it be useful to map the data to the template, press a button and - BAM! - loads of content based on the template with the data from your collection?I think so.---This plugin is completely free so feel free to not buy me a [coffee](https://buymeacoffee.com/shragor)Although... if you did, you could leave a message asking for functional upgrades which I would consider ü§î---## How the thing works1. Install the plugin in Figma (you should know how to do this)2. Pick the frame you want to use as a template3. Alter the fieldNames you want populated with your JSON data - note, change the name of the field, not the value - by surrounding them like {{this}}4. Open the plugin (you can do this at any time tbh)5. Click "Load JSON File" to load your JSON file (check next section for the required format)6. If your frame is not selected, select it by clicking its name7. JSON Frame Mapper will attempt to map {{fieldNames}} to Fields8. You can manually change the mapping of fieldNames to JSON fields if you want to9. Set "Generation Settings". Frames are generated from left to right starting from the right of the template (so make sure you have room!)10. Frame separation sets the number of pixels between generated frames11. Max horizontal frames sets the maximum number of frames generated to the right before it moves to a new line below the first generated frames12. The "Generate Frames" button is there but I don't remember why. Give it a shot and see if anything happens---## The dataCurrently the **JSON Frame Mapper** accepts only a JSON in this form:```[{"name": [Item 1's name/title],"field1": [VALUE],"field2": [VALUE],...},{"name": [Item 2's name/title],"field1": [VALUE],"field2": [VALUE],...},...]```So, an array of objects with key/value pairs or fields of whatever you want to call them.In my use case, the keys correspond to column headings in a spreadsheet I output to JSON. Each row beneath the column headings is a single item I want to use with the template.---## Other stuff- The plugin will look for a JSON field of "name", "Name", "title" or "Title" and use it as the name for the generated frame- On successfully loading a JSON, it will display the number of items and fields such as ```25 items with 23 fields loaded```- It looks for {{fieldNames}} whenever a frame is selected so you can deselect or select another frame/template after the JSON is loaded- You can't load another or different JSON once you have loaded the first one. Unfortunately, the only way you can change JSON once loaded is:1. Closing the Plugin2. Exiting Figma3. Uninstalling Figma4. Uninstalling Windows or if Mac, upgrade your Mac to the latest silicon5. Reinstalling Windows or opening your new Mac6. Installing Figma7. Installing JSON Frame Mapper Plugin8. Opening the Plugin- Note: only steps 1 and 8 are required for most people to clear the JSON file## Similar plugins I tried and didn't like- JSON -> content- Google Sheets Sync- Google Sheets ‚Üí Figma- Data Lab- Google Sheets Sync- Data Populator- others I can't remember## Language clarificationYou *probably* don't need to read this.*Frame* = A Figma frame, you should know what this is. It will contain your Template*Template* = A frame where you have all the design done and text fields in place but need lots of versions of each with different text (which is in your JSON file)*fieldNames* = The name for a field/text field etc. in your Figma Frame/Template. Some of these will contain the text you want lots of different versions of*Item* = An individual thing in your JSON file which contains many Fields each with the data you want to map to your fieldNames and add to your Template*Fields* = These are the names/titles/keys of the data in your JSON. Each Item will have one or more of these and each Field can be mapped to none, one or many fieldNames in the Template*Value* = The actual value for a given Field of a given Item in your JSON. Hopefully, this will eventually appear in a Template if everything goes well*Map* = Linking of a fieldName to a Field
plugins.tagline: Create new instances of a frame/template from JSON data

networkAccess.reasoning: This plugin allows users to load images and data from their local development servers. Users often run local servers on common ports (3000, 4000, 5000, 8000, 8080, 9000) to serve images, SVG files, and JSON data that they want to import into their Figma designs. Localhost access enables seamless integration with local development workflows and self-hosted content.

137181.release_notes:
Now accepts and imports SVGs.

If an object {{field}} (a rectangle or square, say) is mapped to a SVG, the object will be replaced by a frame containing a group of the SVG. The SVG will be exactly the same size, shape and location (in the design) as the parent {{field}}
137181.tagline: Create new instances of a frame/template from JSON data

Choose from free, hardcoded industry templates or use AI to generate custom content and color schemes tailored to your business. Perfect for designers, agencies, and business owners who want to jumpstart their web projects with best-practice layouts and content.Key Features* One-click wireframe generation for 12+ industries (landscaping, tech, law, etc.)* AI-powered content and color palette generation (with the option to use your own OpenAI API key)* Customizable sections, layouts, and color schemes* No coding required‚Äîeverything happens inside FigmaInstructions1. Open the plugin in your Figma file.2. Select your industry and customize sections, layouts, and colors as desired.3. (Optional) Enter your OpenAI API key to unlock AI-powered content and color generation.4. Click ‚ÄúGenerate Wireframe‚Äù to add a complete landing page wireframe to your canvas.5. Edit and iterate as needed!

plugins.name: Figmata
plugins.description: Figmata is a tool that brings data visualization into the Figma environment, letting designers map data directly onto design elements with live, visual feedback. Unlike rigid chart tools like Excel or Illustrator, Figmata enables custom, flexible, and interactive graphics‚Äîintegrated into the design systems designers already use. It lowers the barrier to entry compared to D3 by working within Figma's component-based structure and offering code autocompletion for advanced users. Figmata supports CSV/JSON input, direct manipulation of visual properties, and saves state for iterative work. It bridges the gap between data and UI design, making data-rich interfaces more intuitive and design-friendly.
plugins.tagline: Data-driven design directly in Figma

plugins.name: Feed Names, Get Frames (16:9, 1280x720)
plugins.description: This plugin allows to batch-create 1280*720px (16:9) frames with user-defined names.The frames will be created in the centre of the viewport, unless something is in the way ‚Äî¬†in this case it will place them to the bottom right of the conflicting element, and the frames created will remain selected for further batch manipulation. Frame size works well for YouTube thumbnails.Useful for established design workflows, especially centred around YouTube design, with high volumes and short turnaround times.Assuming that 1 manual frame creation+naming takes 5 seconds, then for 10 frames the plugin increases the efficiency by x50. And even more for a larger number of frames.

plugins.name: Maruco
plugins.description: What is this?Maruco is a plugin that provides rules and validation for component naming, helping you identify components that violate naming conventions and elements.1. Selecting naming convention.There are several conventions, let's select the best one for your project.2. Entering naming elements.Next, you can enter "words" that makes up the component's name.Enter a comma between words to set multiple words.Maruco guesses that the component's name is made up of three elements: a prefix, a middle word and a suffix.3. Running validation.That's all. Let's run the validation.

plugins.name: ÊâìÂç∞Â∑•ÂÖ∑ Figma Print Pro
plugins.description: IntroductionFigma Print Pro is a specialized plugin that helps you create print-ready documents directly in Figma. Easily set up standard or custom page sizes, add bleed areas and crop marks, export high-quality PDFs in multiple color formats, and ensure professional results with built-in DPI checks.Function DescriptionCustom & Preset Dimensions: Choose from popular print sizes (A4, A3, B5) or enter exact dimensions.Bleed & Crop Marks: Add bleed lines and crop marks to prepare for professional trimming.Multi-page Documents: Generate multi-page print layouts all within a single Figma file.Color Management: Export PDFs in RGB, CMYK, or grayscale for precise color control.Adjustable Image Quality: Downsample images and set compression levels to optimize file size.DPI Checks: Analyze frames to confirm whether resolution meets professional print standards.UsageSet Up a Document: In the plugin panel, pick a preset size (A4, A3, B5) or enter your custom width and height.Adjust Settings: Define bleed margins, enable crop marks, and specify the page count.Preview: The plugin generates a quick visual preview of each page.Export to PDF: Choose a color format (RGB, CMYK, or grayscale), select image quality settings, then export.Check DPI: Run the DPI check tool to ensure images and frames meet print-quality standards.TipsRecommended DPI: For most print jobs, 300 DPI is standard. Ensure your images and frames meet or exceed this resolution.Color Consistency: When using CMYK, note that colors may differ slightly from on-screen previews.Bleed Setup: If your printer requires a bleed, confirm the exact measurement specifications with your print provider.Downsampling: Keep an eye on image clarity if you significantly reduce the DPI to minimize file size.‰ªãÁªçFigma Print Pro plugins.name: Fair Colors
plugins.description: Fair Colors is a Figma plugin designed to streamline your color workflow, helping you manage, apply, and audit colors within your designs.Key Features:Extract Colors: Quickly grab all unique colors from your current selection, including solid fills and gradients.Organize Palettes: Create and manage multiple color palettes, giving them custom names for easy organization.Apply & Replace: Effortlessly apply saved colors to selected layers or replace existing colors throughout your selection.Smart Highlighting: Instantly highlight all layers in your canvas that use a specific color, making auditing and adjustments a breeze.Track Changes: Identify and manage color discrepancies by generating a "Fair Colors Changes" frame that visually shows differences between your saved palette and colors found in your selection.Export Tokenized Colors: Generate a clean, tokenized reference frame of your used colors, perfect for design system documentation or developer handoff.Fair Color helps you maintain consistency, identify rogue colors, and accelerate your design process by putting powerful color management tools right at your fingertips.
plugins.tagline: Local Color Palette System
